poem:
**Balancing Act**

In the arena's light,  
Starmer's tightrope sways;  
beneath, the urgent sighs  
of budgets yet untied.  
York-Smith counts, a judge  
with seasoned eyes,  
as policy vaults high  
and spins mid-air—  
will fall, or land?  
The chancellor blinks,  
audience breathes,  
the wire hums electric,  
on this crafted breeze.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Reshuffle gymnastics prepare Starmer to walk tricky budget tightrope Dan York-Smith, the former senior Treasury official Keir Starmer has appointed as his principal private secretary, is a qualified international gymnastics judge – a skill set that may come in handy as Labour limbers up for the formidable balancing act of Rachel Reeves’s autumn budget. After a dizzying series of backflips on tax and spending, some of which were blamed squarely on the chancellor, the government". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
